answers.answer: I have also had bilateral oophorectomy for complex ovarian cysts.  Please talk to your doctor and have them run a COMPLETE thyroid panel including antibodies.Estrogen, progesterone and thyroid hormones are all interrelated and affect each other.http://mend.endojournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/11/11/1581http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=38035http://www.fibrocystic.com/thyroid.htmI've also had my thyroid out for papillary carcinoma and the balancing act between all the meds is very delicate (especially since I'm taking myself off the HRT now because of breast cancer in my family).Ensuring your thyroid levels are in balance is very critical but often overlooked.Here's a bit more about thyroid.  Look up the symptoms of hypothyroidism, I think you'll be surprised.http://www.endocrineweb.com/http://www.cumc.columbia.edu/dept/thyroid/After your doctor runs your (complete) thyroid panel, please find an endocrinologist who specializes in thyroids (many only deal with diabetes - which is ANOTHER concern for us).Hang in there, hypothyroidism can be terrible and the depression that comes with it, if left untreated, can be debilitating.  Please, talk to your doctor.
